Fun one on a topic asked a few times (that I have answered before hitting this speed bump) -> finding out if a user owns a given serial inside the SC.

```
IERC721(_claimNFT).ownerOf(serials[i]) == msg.sender

A couple of questions:

2) Is there another way to check the ownership, so I do not squander child transactions toward this limit?

Author: deejay0076
Content:
so HTS FT/NFTs do not support ERC20Burnable/ERC721Burnable so I implemented that with a SC wrapper. 

```
function burnToken(address token, uint64 amount, int64[] memory serialNumbers) internal
    returns (int responseCode, uint64 newTotalSupply)
    {
        (bool success, bytes memory result) = precompileAddress.call(
            abi.encodeWithSelector(IHederaTokenService.burnToken.selector,
            token, amount, serialNumbers));
        (responseCode, newTotalSupply) =
        success
        ? abi.decode(result, (int32, uint64))
        : (HederaResponseCodes.UNKNOWN, 0);
    }
```

this is from the Hedera pre-compiles and works for FT (token/amount) or NFT (token, serial array **do not send amount)

to burn a token it has to be in the treasury account, so my NFT implementation transfers them to the SC that was the minting treasury and then burns them.

Of course a wipe key is not ideal for trust but if you mint from the SC, leave the SC as the wipe key then encapsulate access control to msg.sender then you can ensure the user is control but you can still achieve the use case.

Author: alberto-IoBuilders#0345
Content: The Hedera HTS precompiled contract uses an "approve()" method to set the allowance for a spender. Isn't a "Approve Race Condition" vulnerability?

Author: Greg Scullard#5365
Content: How so ?

Author: alberto-IoBuilders#0345
Content: I did not find any "increaseAllowance" or "decreaseAllowance" methods on the HTS precompiled contract (maybe I am missing something). If we need to change a spender's allowance the only option is to "reset" it using "approve()", but in the meantime(time for the reset transaction to be added to the DLT) the spender can spend his/her current allowance, which means that he/she will eventually have had the possibility to spend the original allowance plus the new one

Author: Greg Scullard#5365
Content: as far as I know, approve doesn't increase the existing allowance, it replaces it with the new allowance, so if the allowance is 10 and you approve 5, the allowance becomes 5 (I could be wrong)

Author: alberto-IoBuilders#0345
Content: that's exactly what approve does, and that is why the vulnerability exists. I initially approve 10, I change my mind and I want to allow you to spend only 5, I send a new approve, but in the meantime you spend those 10. Once my new approve arrives, you have already spent 10 (your allow balance is 0), now you can spend 5. Result : you can potentially spend 15....

Author: alberto-IoBuilders#0345
Content: if instead of approving 5, I "decrease" the allow balance by 5, worst case scenario you can only spend 10 (the initial allowance), my transaction decreasing the allowance will fail...

Author: Greg Scullard#5365
Content: I believe the implementation matches how an ERC20 contract works, not saying it's right.

Author: Greg Scullard#5365
Content: Maybe the process would be to remove the allowance first, check if the spender has spent anything and only re-approve the delta (or nothing) ?

Author: alberto-IoBuilders#0345
Content: yes of course that would avoid the problem, but it is a multi-step process to be carried out by the user

I see from the 0.36 release notes this is now in testnet.

----
"An EOA (externally owned account) will have to provide explicit approval/allowance to a contract if they want the contract to transfer value from their account balance."

I know in Eth land we have a two step approval process borne out of necessity not usability - hopefully it was not an attempt to mimic that üò≠ (potentially 3 step on Hedera, associate, approve, interact...granted I try to make it as seamless as possible and associate inside the contract call but wanted to illustrate the point).

Author: bugbytes
Content: ....so is, or is this not ...  a divergence for how the EVM works on other ledgers?  (Reason I ask, the whole allowance thing was for the purpose of making HTS "behave like other ledgers" - notably Ethereum)

Author: deejay0076
Content:
it's more like ETH, this is true, in the raw sense. Unfortunately ETH has to scaffold up every token given no native token service so the analogy breaks (my opinion).

For example, if I deployed the project on ETH I would use an ERC-1155 for all the NFT collections and the Fungible Token.  As a result it could be 1 approval for the user to sign to give the contract permission to interact with all tokens. Plus there would be no association step. So 2 messages (approval / interact) to sign.

By virtue of HTS - which I appreciate so very much vs standing up basic architecture every time - each minted NFT token is separate. As such if I then need to interact with my staking contract I have to ask the user to sign to grant approval of all serials of each NFT collection on top of the association step. 

net/net: it's a choice between a high friction and ultimately poor user experience, or restructuring all collections onto a single jumbo token to mimic (poorly) ERC-1155 which is a rubbish experience for other reasons. 

---
Said differently, just because it looks like ETH in the basic case does not always make it right. I am keen to keep the benefits of HTS not force ourselves to the dark ages of rolling ERC20/721/1155 just to be more ETH like.

with the change to the security model, the SC no longer has the permission of the user to act as the user on an implicit basis.

- transferNFT/FT, then you need to grant allowances to the contract explictly, then shift to using the allowance mechanisms.

those are the three categories I have hit so far, not claiming it to be an exhaustive list.

Author: deejay0076
Content: GM - HTS methods are priced to a fiat $ cost (paid in hbar). Gas is also translated into an hbar cost. There is a max gas per (pseudo) block at 15mm. The hbar equivalent cost for a mint via HTS is above the hbar cost for 15mm in gas hence you need to use a payable method and pass hbar value. Using a simpler (read cheaper) HTS method like associate ($0.05) then it can simply pay with gas as is your intuition. Hope I have been coherent here - not this is from empirical experience playing with HTS via SDK and via Solidity for some time vs an official stance.

responseCode = success ? abi.decode(result, (int32)) : HederaResponseCodes.UNKNOWN;

Author: ed.marquez
Content:
`TokenCreateTransaction` is one of the more (if not the most) expensive transactions (see fee schedule: https://docs.hedera.com/hedera/networks/mainnet/fees#token-service). 

The price of the tx often exceeds the gas limits that can be set, specially if you customize the token with things like custom royalties, etc. (See fee calculator for impact of each field/customization: https://hedera.com/fees). 

Since the fee of the tx can exceed the gas limit that can be set, the user must specify the fee value as a `payable` amount.

Author: ed.marquez
Content:
Yes - it's doable with the SDK.

1. Check this example for reference: https://github.com/ed-marquez/hedera-example-create-nft-solidity/blob/2d5308b5c377c61978b6a351a109a0f23c978f0c/index.js#L64C52-L64C52
^ That specific example is slightly different because it uses the client rather than the HashPack signer. However, should be similar enough.
Basically, once you get the record with the signer, try something like:
`const tokenIdSolidityAddr = createTokenRx.contractFunctionResult.getAddress(0);`

2. Another way is to get the record, then do a record query with `TransactionRecordQuery` (https://docs.hedera.com/hedera/sdks-and-apis/sdks/transactions/get-a-transaction-record), set `setIncludeChildren()` to `true` and then use the debugger to navigate the result (the token ID is somewhere in there)

Content: If getting the info from mirror nodes, keep in mind that it's best practice to allow for 3-5 seconds to elapse so that the info can be spread from consensus nodes to mirror nodes.
